spatial_accuracy.notes: Overall massing resembles the plan (4 bedrooms around a central living/dining + kitchen), but several spaces are simplified or shifted. (E2/E4) Top-side decks are not represented with correct segmentation/shape: the plan has two distinct decks (large deck along living side + smaller deck off Bed-1), while the 3D shows a single continuous/ambiguous balcony strip. (E2/E4) The bottom service core (HQ + two small toilets) is not clearly preserved as separate rooms; the bottom zone reads as a simplified corridor/void. (E1/E2) Door placement/orientation cannot be verified accurately because openings are either missing or not placed where the plan indicates multiple hinged doors (foyer entry, bedroom doors, toilet doors). (E2/E3) Window placement is inconsistent: long continuous openings at the top edge do not match the plan’s discrete window/door openings to the decks and room windows. (E2) Proportions are distorted in multiple rooms/circulation widths (e.g., living/dining depth vs. kitchen/foyer band), with corridors appearing widened and some rooms appearing more square than in plan. (E4)

structural_fidelity.notes: Wall thickness is rendered fairly consistently, but interior partitions are simplified, especially in the bottom (foyer/HQ/toilets) and right-side wet areas. (E4) Door embedding correctness is weak: several expected door openings (to toilets, foyer, utility) are not clearly cut/located as per plan. (E2/E3) Adjacencies are partially correct (kitchen adjacent to dining; bedrooms grouped), but the plan’s specific service adjacency (utility + common toilet cluster near center-right; HQ/toilet cluster at bottom) is not faithfully maintained. (E2) At least one room cluster appears missing/merged (HQ and the two small toilets at bottom). (E1) No clear evidence of additional fully new rooms, but the balcony/deck configuration reads as a hallucinated merge of two decks into one continuous element. (E5)

furniture_mapping.notes: Living/dining furniture is broadly plausible (sofa grouping + dining table), and beds are placed in each bedroom, but the plan’s deck furniture and several bathroom/kitchen fixtures are absent or not mapped to the labeled spaces. (E1/E2) Furniture scale is inconsistent in places (oversimplified blocks; some beds and dining set appear disproportionate to room sizes). (E4)

aesthetic_quality.notes: Camera is closer to a top-down/isometric but lacks clear true isometric read (weak depth cues, minimal perspective). Lighting is flat with low contrast, reducing readability of walls/doors/windows. Geometry is generally clean, but the render is blurry/low-detail, making openings and partitions hard to verify (rendering clarity issue). (E6)

detected_errors.description: Deck configuration is incorrect: plan has two distinct decks (large along living + smaller off Bed-1) but 3D shows a single continuous/ambiguous top balcony strip.
Top exterior edge shape and deck segmentation are proportionally simplified; the characteristic angled/stepped outline is not faithfully preserved.
Bottom service rooms (HQ 6'9"x7' and the two small toilets at the bottom band) are missing or merged into an undefined corridor/space.
Utility/common-wet-area partitioning near the center-right does not match the plan’s distinct utility and toilet layout.
Door locations for toilets/foyer/utility and several bedroom entries are not shown where the plan indicates; openings are unclear or absent.
Door orientation (hinge/swing direction) cannot be matched; the 3D does not preserve the plan’s door-swing logic.
Window placement is inconsistent: long continuous top openings do not correspond to the plan’s discrete windows/door-to-deck openings per room.
Room and corridor proportions differ from plan (circulation appears widened; some bedrooms/living areas appear reshaped toward more uniform rectangles).
Hallucinated/merged exterior element: the two-deck scheme is effectively replaced by a single continuous balcony feature.
Render blur/low detail reduces verifiability of openings and partitions (visual clarity artifact).
